WRITING.TITLE: Looking for a simple 20" bike for my son
WRITING.TEXT: I'm not much of a bicyclist, so I have an elementary question. My son hasn't learned to bike yet, and he's too big for the 16" kids bikes. But all the 20" bikes I see seem to have lots of gears and bells and whistles. What's the best place I could get him a bike to learn on?
When I'm at work, I use http://steep.it to set a timer to remind me to check.

Lots of great advice here (and from others).
Do what you're comfortable with, but don't be scared of anti-depressants. If you broke your leg, you'd take painkillers. You wouldn't say "oh, it's natural and lots of people have pain and get through it." (Or at least I wouldn't.)
My wife took anti-depressants for her post-partum depression (in addition to therapy) and it helped a great deal.
The other thing I would say is: acknowledge her pain. Don't just say everything is sunny, but say "I know it's tough not to go to work. I hear you. It's hard."
This is the best and spiffiest answer.

WRITING.TITLE: An autistic son leaves the nest

WRITING.TEXT: I would never have been able to take an overnight trip with my twins before age 5 without having a minivan to take all the stuff. Just sayin'
BG twins

True story: a MOT that I knew was walking her infant twins in a stroller in Harvard Yard, and the Dalai Lama is walking by. He stops to look at them and then asks "which was born first?"
Which is a long way of saying that there are a bunch of standard, stupid questions that people ask when they see parents of multiples, and even the Dalai Lama isn't immune. I suspect that your hygienist is not as wise as he is. Just ignore her. And expect to get asked it a lot more before your triplets are grown.

I was a lot older when I had my kids, and it still felt like a huge amount of responsibility that I wasn't ready for. So remember, what you're feeling is felt by every other Dad out there. It's scary.
Best piece of advice I ever got: it's a marathon, not a sprint. You'll make mistakes. But the mistakes that seem huge at nine months you won't remember in five years (and neither will your son).
In Massachusetts, its police stations. And here the Federal Government will help you find who does it near you: http://www.nhtsa.gov/cps/CPSFitting/Index.cfm
Yes, at age 9 1/2 we still use them, too. Recently had to replace the one that had lasted seven years, though.

Yeah, don't assume that the Monster Truck phase will last. Kids change their interests every year. But encourage your son to find the things that interest him. And continue to expose him to things that are important to you. It may stick eventually.
And maybe there's some things you can explore that would appeal to you both: model rocketry? Building robots?

WRITING.TEXT: Actually they've rebuilt and are reopening in a mere 55 days. http://www.bostonteapartyship.com/

Most tea snobs (myself included) generally go for brewing loose tea. But by all means, start out with bags and the commercial sweetener of your choice to ease into it.
Bigelow is probably your best choice for decent teabags that are available in regular supermarkets. Their Constant Comment is nice an orangey; they also have Earl Grey and Plantation Mint that I like. Once you get past that, you're probably going to want to order online.
I'd advise against starting with Herbal tea or Green tea -- they're just not going to be flavorful enough for you, and not going to have enough caffeine to make you feel anything.
I think most everything within a mile of the common has been fixed up already, since those neighborhoods started getting rehabbed in the 70s.

The Somerville Winter Farmers' Market runs until May 26 on Saturdays (which makes it kind of a winter-spring market) https://twitter.com/#!/somwintermarket
Unfortunately, given the New England climate, there typically isn't a whole lot of locally-grown food available until June. This year might be different, but that doesn't mean the Farmers' Markets are adapting their schedule.
Edit: Probably more convenient to you, the SoWA Market on Harrison opens this Sunday: http://www.sowaopenmarket.com/
